DOC.HEAD: Unofficial Count Calls Collor de Mello Winner in Brazilian Election
Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE vote totals, unofficial winner might be announced today, current president offering to resign early; Picks up 6th graf, `Globo TV ...'
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of socialist presidential candidate Luis Inacio da Silva refused to concede defeat and accused the nation's biggest television network and private bus companies of sabotaging their campaign. The official tally today had conservative free-market advocate Fernando Collor de Mello leading da Silva by 2.46 million votes, with 90.36 percent of the ballots counted in Brazil's first direct presidential election in 29 years. The winner could be announced this afternoon, Superior Electoral Court spokesman Irineu Tamanini said. Final results will be known by Wednesday, he said. Out-going President Jose Sarney said he would step down from office early if Congress voted to shorten his five-year mandate. ``If the Congress wishes, I won't be an obstacle,'' said Sarney, a civilian who took office in 1985 to end a 21-year right-wing military regime. Sarney was chosen in an Electoral College vote coordinated by Brazil's top generals. The new president is scheduled to succeed Sarney for a five-year term March 15. However, pressure is mounting for Sarney to resign early to allow the new president to adopt emergency economic measures. News of Collor de Mello's lead stabilized financial markets Monday and triggered a plunge of the dollar on the illegal, but tolerated, black market. Globo TV, the nation's biggest network, on Monday projected Collor de Mello would defeat da Silva by 6.27 percent of total votes cast. The conservative candidate led by 3 million votes, or 5.1 percent of valid ballots, in the network's unofficial tally, which was based on 86.8 percent of returns announced by state election officials. The owner of Globo TV, media tycoon Roberto Marinho, supported Collor de Mello during the campaign. Officials of da Silva's Workers Party said they would sue the network, accusing it of giving Collor de Mello more television time in news broadcasts in the days leading up to the vote. The party officials also accused the network of portraying the conservative candidate in a more favorable light than his leftist adversary. All TV time during Brazilian elections is strictly controlled by the Supreme Electoral Court. ``We'll follow this to the last vote and show the Court how much Globo TV influenced the election's outcome,'' said Workers Party President Luiz Gushiken. Federal Police Chief Romeu Tuma said officials were investigating charges by the Workers Party that voters couldn't reach polling stations in the states of Bahia and Ceara _ both strong da Silva regions _ because private bus companies pulled their vehicles off the streets. Collor de Mello, 40, advocates free-market policies and moral cleanup in government. He says Brazil's $110 billion foreign debt, the largest in the Third World, should be paid, but under less burdensome conditions. Brazil's business, military and media establishments have closed ranks behind Collor de Mello, who comes from a prominent family in the northeastern state of Alagoas, long established in politics. The Marxist-oriented de Silva, 44, has ured immediate suspension of payments on the foreign debt, and advocates sweeping land, urban reform and the redistribution of income. Brazilians on Sunday cast ballots to choose a successor to President Jose Sarney for a five-year term in a historic vote marking the return of democratic rights after 21 years of military rule. The country of 150 million people has 82 million registered voters. Sarney is a civilian but gained office through a military-coordinated Electoral College vote in 1985. Da Silva was bouyed early in the official count by returns from the major southern cities of Porto Alegre and Rio de Janeiro, his main strongholds. But Collor de Mello overtook da Silva when returns came in from remote central and northern regions, where the conservative had an edge. Collor de Mello appeared briefly Monday afternoon outside his Brasilia mansion, waving and making a victory sign. He made no comment on the count to reporters. Da Silva and Collor de Mello were the top vote-getters in a field of 21 candidates in first-round balloting Nov. 15. Neither obtained a majority needed to win so the runoff was held.
